entry.title: Taimodels Releases Cairns Airport for X-Plane 11 & 12
entry.summary: Sim: X-Plane. Taimodels has recently released their rendition of Cairns Airport (YBCS) for X-Plane 11 and 12, serving the city of Cairns in Queensland, Australia, with a yearly average of 5 million passengers. â The airport was built in 1936 on 162 hectares of land bought by the Cairns City Council, originally sporting three runways made of cinders, red earth, weathered rock, and sand. Then, in the early 1940s, the Australian Government purchased the airport to adapt it for RAF use, paving and lengthening the main runway to comport larger aircraft. â Twenty years later, the airport was upgraded to receive jet aircraft, with an expansion and a runway extension followed by extensive flattening. â With the ever-growing passenger traffic figures, there was pressure in the late 1970s to expand the passenger terminal, which went on to happen in 1982. Finished two years later, it was just the first stage of three. The whole ordeal ended in 1997 with the conclusion of a three-story Airport Administration Center. â In 2007, the domestic terminal was redeveloped, costing the administration around 200 million Australian Dollars.Â â The last upgrade started in 2019 and was completed a year later, increasing the departure hall area and adding dining and retail facilities. Itâs part of their plan to prepare the airport for handling up to 6 million passengers annually from 2027. â In early 2023, they announced the first major upgrade to the international terminal, rolling out in stages to minimize passenger disruption. â Itâs a hub for QantasLink and Skytrans Airlines and served by Air New Zealand, Air Niugini, Airnorth, Alliance Airlines, Asia Pacific Airlines, Bonza, Hinterland Aviation, Jetstar, PNG Air, Qantas, Rex Airlines, Singapore Airlines, Virgin Australia. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with high-detail models, SAM jetways, PBR texturing, custom autogen, ground traffic plugins, and weather textures (XP12).Â â Itâs available onÂ SimMarketÂ for roughly $19.18, requiring at least 1.51 GB of free hard disk space to install. Stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news!

entry.title: Fly2High Releases Jacksonville International Airport for MSFS
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Fly2High has recently released their rendition of Jacksonville International Airport (KJAX) for Microsoft Flight Simulator, serving the Jacksonville Metropolitan Area with a yearly average of 6,500,000 passengers. Jacksonville International was conceived as a replacement for Imeson Field, which has served Jacksonville since 1927. It was simply not big enough to handle the increased demand for air travel, and the runways could not be expanded due to terrain limitations.Â â The airport's growth could have been faster, with only two million passengers annually by 1982 (way below expectation). However, the 90s saw a massive increase, with the average hitting the 5 million mark. In 2000, they approved an expansion plan to rebuild the landside terminal, central square, main concessions area, and a parking area expansion. â In 2006, they rolled out the second phase of the expansion program, rebuilding concourses A and C, designed by Reynolds, Smith & Hills. The crisis of 2009 stopped any other ongoing expansion work, with the old Concourse B being demolished and only considered for rebuilding ten years later when the traffic figures were healthy again. The pandemic, though, halted that project. â Allegiant Air, American Airlines, American Eagle, Breeze Airways, Delta Air Lines, Delta Connection, Frontier Airlines, JetBlue, Silver Airways, Southwest Airlines, Sun Country Airlines, United Airlines, and United Express serve it. American, Delta, and Southwest hold most of the market share, with 20% each. â The scenery features an accurate rendition of the airport, with hand-made ground textures, custom lighting, high-detail models, and performance-friendly optimization. â It's available on theÂ iniBuilds StoreÂ for roughly $17.78, requiring at least 5.89 GB of free hard disk space to install. entry.title: Just Flight Provides Avro Vulcan Progress Update
entry.summary: Sim: MSFS. Just Flight has released an update on their upcoming Avro Vulcan for Microsoft Flight Simulator via their website today. The Avro Vulcan, developed by Avro/Hawker Siddeley, is a British bomber that took its first flight in August 1952. The Vulcan, also known as the V bomber, was developed as part of the British atomic weapon program, designed as a medium-range bomber with the capability of carrying one 10,000 lb. bomb over a distance of 1,500 NM. It can also carry standard bomb loads of up to 20,000 LBS. The Vulcan's iconic shape is attributed to its delta wing design, which provides stability without the need for a horizontal stabilizer. The original Vulcan was powered by the Rolls Royce Olympus 201/301 low bypass turbojet engine, capable of producing up to 20,000 pounds of thrust and enabling the Vulcan to reach speeds of up to 561 knots with a service ceiling of 55,000 Feet. The aircraft was in service with the Royal Air Force until October 2015, when it was officially retired. Just Flight is focusing on the Vulcan B Mk. 2 XM655, which is located in Wellesbourne Airfield. The simulation will include air-to-air refueling and maritime radar reconnaissance variants that were once used by the Royal Air Force. This progress update provides information on the progress made on the project by Just Flight. To ensure the Vulcan's unique engine sounds are perfect, Just Flight is "holding back" on the sound preview video. The team has made significant improvements on the interior and exterior lighting and other functionalities of the EFB app. The accuracy of the aircraft lighting has been improved by up to 20 controls in the cockpit using new reference material. Eight switches on the right console will control the exterior lighting, including air-to-air refueling, probe lighting, rotating beacons, and other indicational lighting. The EFB has new features and user interface improvements, such as a configuration menu that allows for the toggling of various aircraft equipment. Fuel menus let you see quantities without using MSFS menus, and they also include options to control Air to Air Refueling. The radio system is also being worked on to improve operational flow for the user. The Vulcan's complex radio system will be streamlined for better usage in the sim. Just Flight has not published a release date, but it indicates the release is on the horizon. To read the full update see their website here. â As always stay tuned to Threshold for more flight simulation news!
